title: George Mann (cricketer)
text:
Francis George Mann, (6 September 1917 – 8 August 2001) was an English <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er, who played for <a href="Cambridge%20University">Cambridge University</a>, <a href="Middlesex%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Middlesex</a> and <a href="England%20cricket%20team">England</a>. He was born at <a href="Byfleet">Byfleet</a>, Surrey and died at <a href="Stockcross">Stockcross</a>, Berkshire.
As a cricketer, George Mann was a right-handed middle-order batsman. His father, <a href="Frank%20Mann%20%28cricketer%29">Frank Mann</a>, also <a href="English%20cricket%20captains">captained England</a>, making them the first father and son to both captain England. <a href="Colin%20Cowdrey">Colin</a> and <a href="Chris%20Cowdrey">Chris Cowdrey</a> are the only other father and son to have done this for England.
Early life and education.
Mann was born on 6 September 1917 in <a href="Byfleet">Byfleet</a>, <a href="Surrey">Surrey</a>, England. The son of <a href="Frank%20Mann%20%28cricketer%29">Frank Mann</a>, he was the brother of <a href="John%20Pelham%20Mann">John Pelham Mann</a>. He was educated at <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a>, an all-boys <a href="Public%20school%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">public school</a>, and captained the school's cricket XI in 1936. He was also a member of the Eton College Contingent of the <a href="Officer%20Training%20Corps">Officer Training Corps</a>, and reached the rank of <a href="Under%20officer%23United%20Kingdom">cadet under-officer</a>. He studied at <a href="Pembroke%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Pembroke College, Cambridge</a>, graduating with a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> (BA) degree. While at <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">Cambridge</a>, he earned two cricketing <a href="Blue%20%28university%20sport%29">blues</a>, having represented the university in 1938 and 1939.
Military service.
Mann served in the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, having joined up before the outbreak of war. On 8 July 1939, he was <a href="Commissioned%20officer">commissioned</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Welch%20Fusiliers">Royal Welch Fusiliers</a> as a <a href="Second%20lieutenant%23United%20Kingdom%20and%20Commonwealth">second lieutenant</a>. He transferred to the <a href="Scots%20Guards">Scots Guards</a> on 13 March 1940. He was awarded the <a href="Military%20Cross">Military Cross</a> (MC) in 1942. On 28 June 1945, the then <a href="Temporary%20rank">temporary</a> <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> Mann was awarded the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">Distinguished Service Order</a> (DSO) "in recognition of gallant and distinguished services in Italy".
Mann maintained his links with the army after the war. On 8 July 1949, he was moved from the Supplementary Reserve of Officers to the Regular Army Reserve of Officers, and was granted the <a href="honorary%20rank">honorary rank</a> of major. Having reached the age limit, he resigned his commission on 6 September 1967 and was permitted to retain his honorary rank.
Cricketing career.
Mann captained England in each of his seven <a href="Test%20cricket">Test match</a>es, winning two, and drawing the other five; his father had also been captain in every Test he played in. "<a href="Wisden%20Cricketers%27%20Almanack">Wisden</a>" said of Mann: "as a captain he was ideal, zealous to a degree, and considerate in all things at all times". After leading England in South Africa in 1948/49, Mann led his side for two Tests in the following summer, before he stood down, citing inability to participate regularly due to his family's brewing business commitments (<a href="Mann%2C%20Crossman%20%26amp%3B%20Paulin">Mann, Crossman & Paulin</a>).
Mann was chairman of the <a href="Test%20and%20County%20Cricket%20Board">Test and County Cricket Board</a> (TCCB) from 1978 to 1983. He was therefore chairman during the controversy over the <a href="South%20African%20rebel%20tours%23English%20XI%2C%201982">rebel tour</a> which <a href="Geoff%20Boycott">Geoff Boycott</a> and <a href="Graham%20Gooch">Graham Gooch</a> led to South Africa in 1982.
Later life.
Mann was a main board director and retained his position on the new company board when his family brewery merged with <a href="Watney%20Combe%20%26amp%3B%20Reid">Watney Combe & Reid</a> in 1958. He was <a href="Non-executive%20director">non-executive</a> Deputy Chairman of the <a href="Extel">Extel Group</a> from 1980 to 1986.
Mann died on 8 August 2001 in <a href="Stockcross">Stockcross</a>, <a href="Berkshire">Berkshire</a>, England.
Personal life.
In 1949, Mann married Margaret Hildegarde Marshall Clark. Together they had four children: three sons and one daughter. His wife predeceased him, dying in 1995.
Mann's son, <a href="Simon%20Mann">Simon</a>, was sentenced for thirty-four years in <a href="Equatorial%20Guinea">Equatorial Guinea</a> in 2008, on charges related to an attempted <a href="Coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">coup</a> in 2004, but was pardoned on 2 November 2009.
